comment: Corn on the Cobb extra butter, that new house smell (fresh paint).
Corn forward, light profile.  Not a lot of flavor from this one.

Batch No. B817-1; Date 03-07-17 (no idea what the date refers to)

We don't often get Balcones products in NC, and when we do, this and Rumble are the cheapest offerings on the shelves. I picked this up last summer and have avoided it, it's just not my jam. For a product with a 6-month age statement the color and oak influence are insane. If you were unsure what happens in Texas heat, this is a prime example of what it can do.

The nose is a cinnamon bun without vanilla frosting. It is sweet and bready, similar to Brown-Forman products, especially their double oaked offerings. It is sickly sweet on the tongue. Too sweet for my palate, and I have a gigantic sweet tooth. Most BF whiskeys I've had have balanced sugar, oak, and alcohol flavors. That sugar overpowers other nuanced flavors you may get if this was aged in a different climate or had a different mashbill. It tastes very malty to me with the classic malt funk replaced by oak and cinnamon bread.  

My opinion has not changed since I first bought the bottle. It is too damn sweet. It's kind of like George Dickel going off the rails and adding artificial sweetener to its GD12 or BiB. Actually for me the closest comparison is Rua American Single Malt. Yes I know this is corn and that is malted barley, but I think the similarities in flavor come from aging. Balcones has that Texas heat, Rua has NC heat combined with aging in small barrels. I think the flavor in both is primarily influenced by the oak barrels and not the new make itself. Because the Rua wasn't as sweet and had more complex flavors, I enjoyed it much more. If you are interested in corn whiskey I suggest trying something cheaper first.
Full strength True Blue is quite good, but this watered down bastardization is neither pleasant, nor balanced. Use your money for something more worthwhile.
Tasty - not sure I'm a big corn whiskey guy, but definitely tasty.
Baby blue only cements my love of Balcones spirits and corn whiskey. The only thing I don't like about it: how fast it disappears!
Buttery sweet. Kind of odd but in a good way.

First time trying corn whiskey, at Nihon in San Francisco. 

 not overly sweet, very pleasant aroma, and an almost peppery bite at the end without having a bitter alcohol chemical flavor like many whiskeys.
Great whiskey, toasted corn on the nose with a distinct sweetness. Spicy on the palate with a long smooth finish.
All bananas foster and whipped cream on the nose, as you pull the glass away there is a hint of oatmeal with brown sugar. Sweet caramel taste, light burn, and banas at the finish.
Strong nose of banana. Fairly smooth and sweet but just not enough flavor for me.
A good little corn whiskey. A little bit of funk on the end that makes it unique.

This was a gift from a friend, I waited to open it... Very unique whisky, floral, one of those that leaves you guessing. Complex whisky I must say, definitely on my top 10 list.  Can't wait to try the brimstone he brought me also.
Hints of caramel and very strong corn taste.
Not a fan -- the nose is more like tequila than whiskey

I tried this at a bar, first straight, then with a cube. Can't say it's a bad whiskey; far from it. But I couldn't get past the plumes of campfire smoke on the back end to the more floral notes I could tell were underneath. Maybe I'll try it again another time, but I'm guessing that's just me being polite to an inanimate bottle of whiskey.
Caramel initially. Absolutely no burn. Slight corn scent but not as much as I had anticipated. Color me impressed.
Sweet nose. Light body, good flavor.
Bag of tortilla chips on the nose, strong floral on the palate (tequila taste), green bananas on the finish; wait 30 seconds. Similar boat for me as Corsair Quinoa.

I don't think this whiskey is bad, but I don't like it. The nose is sweet, and buttery, full of corn, and something like tequila. Then I get this funky hit around the back, something oniony and sour. And it's there on the palate as well. It reminds me of sour cream and onion chips, just nowhere near as strong (or disgusting). It's not as apparent if you don't add water. Yeah, not for me. Well crafted though.

Alcohol is strong on the initial nose then a very pleasant nuttiness. The pallet is sweet with corn, just a little burn on the front of the tung. Mouth fell is nice goes down smooth with little burn in the belly. I like it.
Smooth and one of the few whiskeys I'll drink by itself.
Not a fan. Smelt like candy corn. Unpleasant front burn. Some incompatible flavors are still battling it out.

Smoky and as many others have said a sweetness of tequila on the nose. A whisky for a tequila bar paired with a fresh made corn chips and southern salsa. Very smooth, ideal for sipping straight. Good to round out my collection so to not only have full bodied Kentucky standards.

I really enjoy the butterscotch on the nose and some of those sweeter caramelized sugar notes but I don’t think it really follows through on the palate. I think those sweeter notes are coming from using the blue corn which I think I may prefer to the standard yellow but this whiskey maybe has not been aged long enough to clear up those more astringent notes. A strong effort but not my choice.
Easy-drinking, slightly sweet corn whiskey. Tasted November 29, 2016 at Murray's Cheese Bar.

Odd but not too off-putting. Malt vinegar (!) initially on the nose, then some sweetness in the form of floral honey and sour caramel.  Palate includes corn, Brazil nuts, earth. Back end is short and slightly bitter. Kind of like a walk on the boardwalk - fries with malt vinegar, saltwater taffy. Not what I was expecting. Adding an ice cube just flattened it out. 1/15/17.

Nose: caramel corn and bananas
Palate: cinnamon, vanilla, caramel, toffee, smooth
Finish: short, a hint of smoke, vanilla
A nice corn whiskey. Water heightens the caramel sweet. Would buy.

Pretty amazing on the nose. Difficult to describe; sweet corn and cotton candy? Taste is not as impressive. Still the sweet corn/candy flavor, but I get a hint of a chemical flavor. a little water and time sitting out does help. Over time I’ve noticed that it definitely grows on me, or maybe oxidation really helps.
A lot of people seem to love it, I must have missed something. Perhaps I should revisit a dram one day.
Must have ice.  Has weird plastic filmy taste at room temp.

Definitely a whiskY. Nose is really sweet, buttery corn. Think tequila... Palate starts sweet, quickly turns buttery with oak, leather, smoky, oily finish.  Tastes nothing like it smells.  It smells immature and tastes aged for a half second, but has a short short finish. It's definitely interesting, but won't buy a 2nd bottle anytime soon.

Had this at Wine Kitchen
Nice, corn-based, slight sweetness
Very sweet candy on the nose, but isn’t too sweet on the palate. Certainly an easy dessert whiskey.
TEQUILA, Lime Cilantro, and Stale Beer
Little brother of Balcones single malt, easy to drink, creamy, vanilla finish.  Good price.
Lots of vanilla especially on finish. Tons of sweet corn. Some smoke as well. Complex for such a young bourbon.

Upon opening the bottle, got some alcohol smell and syrupy sweetness, just from the nose I could tell it was a young whiskey. In the glass it has some nice oiliness to it, with the runners slow and thick on a glass swirl. Alcohol harshness on the front end of the palate, but quickly gave way to a pleasant mix of buttered popcorn and vanilla sweetness. Medium finish that carries the sweetness all the way through. a little water helps open it up and take the front end harshness.  Definitely worth picking up for the uniqueness.
Young and really rough pour. A lot going on which is why I give it the 3rd star fot being interesting. I did not get any sweet notes, all grain.
One of my favorites from the Balcones line. Great Whiskey from nose to finish. Nose was buttery. Palate was a smooth sweat creamy butter. Finish was medium.

(What are the expert eaters thinking?!) 2.6 which I’ll round to 3. Tequila nose. Whiskey palette. Try it at a bar first! Way overpriced for the flavor. It’s not terrible, but I don’t plan to buy again.
Sweet corn syrup smell with taste like crewing on a corn kernel

Day 15. We continue with blue, but instead of a blue label, we get blue corn today. My first corn Whiskey if I remember correctly. On the nose you get hit with a lot of sugar, some corn, marzipan, bit of vanilla and subtle hints of banana. Really aggressivly sweet smell. The taste is not quite as sweet, but still on the high end of sweetness. We get a lot of vanilla, the raw sugar of the nose transformed into a brown, roasted sugar with a bit of banana and cinnamon. The short aftertaste is just sweet vanilla. This is a tasty whiskey for sure, more of a dessert than anything else, but it's a bit one dimensional. Sweet, sweet, and banana. Nice if you're in the mood for sticky sweetness, otherwise grab something else.
Syrupy sweet, but very interesting...there's a time and a place for this one, I think it's in place of dessert
Syrupy, rough vanilla on the tongue, candy corn aftertaste, overall... interesting
Butterfinger candy bar! 100% in nose, palate, and finish... this is sweet, but the butteriness really makes up for that.
Very strong smell. Pretty smooth. Bit of an aftertaste
Tasted at Whiskey Obsession 2018. The Rumble was better.

This is a high fructose corn syrup PSA, this is a sweet whiskey. The nose is vanilla and cream and the palate is banana pudding and Creme Brûlée. The finish is sticky toffee with raisins. This is an easy sipping whiskey, no burn or smoke here.
Not horrible. The nose is filled with candy corn and caramelized bananas. Very sweet even with a higher proof. Good whiskey for beginners not so much people that really love whisk(e)y.
Sweet corn nose, Spicy with a sweet bite
Banana. Sweeter than most. Smooth burn with ease

nose: buttery kettle corn
taste: hot, spicy, barrel, kinda harsh
finish: spicy and leather

strange ride, sweet nose totally different from everything else. Added some water, tamed the heat a bit, but not finding a lot of flavors.
Sweet on the nose. Candy corn. Alcohol. Closer to Scotch than Bourbon on the taste. Smooth light finish. Good stuff.
At Easy Tiger, Austin, TX, July 22, 2018.

This was very tasty for the first and 2nd sip. After that it was all downhill. Sweet corn notes came thru and it became very sickly. A 1oz pour is more than enough. I would never recommend a bottle. Hard pass on this one. 2/5
sweet kettle popcorn, some candy corn, butter.
Good, but not good enough to buy for home
Starts a bit bitter and meh but opens up nicely with a bit of water

I clearly was given the wrong pour before (likely Brimstone). This is all delicious butter popcorn, which is a fabulous addition to a tasting menu, and occasionally a great addition to a regular weekend night. Even if the same not gets hit from start to finish, damn if it ain’t a great note!
Sweet, with a long spicy burn. I like it.

Nose:
    Smells like new whiskey
    Corn syrup
    Marshmallow
    Honeydew melon
    
    Taste:
    Candy Corn
    Marshmallow

Strong vanilla, cinnamon, and chiles on the nose. Flavors are very loud with this whiskey but not harsh. Brown sugar, tea, lemon, and mint on the pallate. The finish is long with cinnamon flavor and leaves a minty sensation in the tongue.
Tried this at the whisky extravaganza. Very innovative approach for Balcones taking on blue corn. It releases notes of caramel, vanilla, and of course corn.

I thought I might like this one at first,  initial sip tasted smooth with a nice subtle corn flavor, but after that initial impression the taste morphed into a sickly sweet version of liquid fritos. Unless you have an unnatural obsession with corn chips I would definitely pass on this on.

Nose candy corn slight vanilla
Pallets vanilla, a bit of oak, cinnamon 
Finish candy corn and spice
I also found this for $20 so overall not bad
Spicy, rich oily mouth feel, and then corn sweetness, toffee and vanilla oak. Too sweet? Nice experiment with blue corn. Young-- may be even better with more time in oak and some smokiness.
liquid candy corn, some oaky flavor on the finish, very sweet
not quite a bourbon, probably why I enjoy it. got movie theatre popcorn butter immediately on the nose and it follows in a really rich way on the taste. a tad spicy as well
Entirely too sweet and tastes young because it is young.  Pales in comparison to their single malt.

Nose: tequila, buttered corn, butterfinger
Taste: oak^10, young, burn, buttery

I wanted to like this but, like all of Balcones, this is way too barrelly. They need to fix this. Small barrels + Texas heat is not a good combination - take one or the other
Mmm. Dark butter toffee, Cracker Jack. Corn sweetness, tons of flavor but easy to drink. After some spicy ryes, this is almost like a dessert treat.
Nose reminded me of a tequila. Wouldn’t recommend.
Full bodied with a strong buttercream palate and spicy fruity notes at the end
nice and smooth, almost a buttery popcorn flavor but my palette could be off 😆
great tasting Texas whiskey especially on the rocks.
unique to me.  like a cousin to bourbon. smooth and sweet.
Tequila nose caught me off guard.
I thought this would drink like a bourbon but it wasn't nearly as sweet, which is great!  it's 100% corn but has some great depth and flavor.
This was very unique and pretty delicious. It reminded me a lot of a low prof version of Colorado 291 Gold. Lots of bold popcorn smell and buttery popcorn flavor.
Interesting and unique... immediate scent of bananas and butterdcotch... first taste is bright... but mellows...and the touch of bananas rides the burn.

Nose: heavy heavy caramel. Vanilla. Toffee. Butterscotch, burnt corn, floral / grassy. 

Taste: candy corn, butterscotch, vanilla, oak, cut grass / hay.

Really lacking in complexity IMO.

Heard a lot about this distillery in the last year or so, and this bottle didn’t disappoint. However not my favorite whiskey I have ever had. The 100% corn may just not be my thing though. 

Nose: candy corn, vanilla, slight hay mustiness. 

Taste: lots of butter scotch on the start, fades quickly into a thick caramel flavor. Finishes off in a dusty candy corn and sugary vanilla. A bit thin and not oily at all. Doesn’t linger very long at all. 

Overall not terrible, but not anywhere close to being great. I hate the taste of candy corn so that may be what’s turning me off. The other flavors on the taste are nice though.

[06.05.19] My initial reaction... dang, this is good. But I was worried it was just an overreaction after the BS that American Airlines has put me through this week (including a near plane wreck). So I obviously kept sipping. This is legit good. 

This tastes like you'd expect a pure corn whiskey to taste. Sweet, pure, with limited barrel flavor. It tastes surprisingly full(?) but I'm not sure what of. Floral/fruity like a subtle Irish whiskey and a bit salty/smoky but nothing distinct. This is smooth with a slight woody after taste, like a blend between those Utica moonshiners and Woodford. Easy drinker straight, this would be dangerous over ice.

For those hopelessly delayed travelers, you can find this at DFW beside gate C10.

Nose: Roasted marshmallow, slight floral, cereal, caramel.

Taste: Sweet tea, more marshmallow, soft caramel candy. 

Experience: A sweets shop, not the new kind with giant Teddy bears and plastic everywhere, but the old kind you might find in a small town or off a pier. 

I feel like corn whiskey deserves it's own category like Irish or rye. It's respectful stuff but distilleries haven't done enough with it. Play around with it and see what you think.

It’s different, then again it’s all corn... On the nose, vinegar up front followed by buttered popcorn and vanilla . On the palate, a rich texture that starts clean followed by a sugary sweetness and strong finish of ethanol and spice.
I’ve never had a corn whiskey this good. Very well done!
Smooth and easy to drink. Like that time when you massaged your aunts feet. She felt it, you felt it, and Marsellus definitely felt it.
Big unique nose of bananas and other fruits.
very earthy and nutty. harsh in the mouth but a smooth finish

One of the most unique bourbons I’ve ever tasted. Caramel bananas up front, think bananas foster. Warm and buttery all the way through, with hint of cinnamon, apple, caramel corn, and cream. Dry finish.
Very light feeling whiskey, definitely sweeter up front, hard to trace sweetness.  Roasted corn does play large in flavor
Lighter and slightly sweeter then expected.

50ml bottle neat in Glencairn at home [came attached as a bonus on a bottle of Balcones classic].  Nose is a smack of popcorn and ethanol, with some dried grass and a hint of sweet caramel.  Taste is more popcorn, less heat, some grass and hay.  Some lingering burnt heat in the back of throat.  Nope, not for me.  6/26/19.
Ethanol on the nose. Not my jam.
Bit of an oily, buttered popcorn nose. Nutty taste with almonds and caramel in the finish.

First foray into both Balcones and 100% corn whiskey in general. Looking forward to something off the beaten path. 

Ok so before we get to far in, let me just say this thing is SWEET. And I mean really sweet, like a sticky bun with extra icing. (Not the flavor components of one, but just trying to illustrate the level of sweetness) 

The nose is powerful; even if you set the glass down away from your face you can still get the occasional whiff wafting from the glass from a few feet away. Rich scents of English toffee, caramel, powdered sugar, and vanilla.  Underneath all the sweet is buttered popcorn. Smells pretty heavenly. 

The palate opens with the toffee from the nose, but quickly switches to various corn flavors. Getting sweet creamed corn as well as stone ground tortilla chips. Just before the finish there's a nice buttery flavor. 

The finish is where things take a downturn. I think the best way to describe it is that it tastes and feels young. There's a grainy harshness which doesn't compliment the nose or palate at all. It's not that it's terribly astringent, it's just not the finish you are craving after what’s already been presented; your tongue wants silky smoothness and instead it gets mugged and has it's wallet stolen. After the harshness fades, there is a lingering flavor of popcorn. It is a short finish and the mouthfeel is medium. 

I think I like the idea of this whiskey better than the whiskey itself. Overall, it's interesting and unique, but the juxtaposition between the palate and finish didn't work for me. That said, I am interested to try other Balcones products as I see where they are going here. At a craft distillery price point of $57, can't say I'd recommend this one.
Light and sweet.  I prefer to have this one aged longer.
Vanilla bean, banana, butter, baking spices popcorn on the nose. Butter, popcorn flavor. Lots of corn, overall very good and unique.
Super buttery sweet butterscotch/toffee on the nose. Much more classic bourbon/corn whiskey taste. Tastes like a higher proof but without the burn. Very unique whiskey and definitely worth a try.
Sweet and fruity with a suprising, pleasant bite. It hits right away with fruit and spice which quickly mellows to a buttery smoothness that holds on to the tongue for a long time.
Smooth, Carmel, vanilla, brown sugar...NO burn. Really a delightful pour!

Killing some time at IAH with this one. Since I apparently can only compare whiskies to dessert items nowadays, this is banana pudding. Banana, vanilla cream, biscuity cookie, and a little hint of caramelized sugar. Rich, round mouthfeel and a sweet, lingering finish. No complaints here.
Nice. very sweet nose. Vanilla and corn. Taste is very sweet but well balanced. Cornbread. Yummy.

Very smooth. The big flavors I get are butter, caramel and corn syrup. I would not complain at all if this were the only thing to choose from at a party. Otherwise, if I never have it again, I would also not complain.

I never do this but I couldn’t help myself - the suggestion seemed so outrageous. Distiller recommends Balcones Baby Blue Corn Whisky if you seek a more floral version of The Macallan 12 Year Old Double Cask (previous tasting). Let’s see just how odd this lineup is. 

Balcones Baby Blue is a corn whisky made from roasted heirloom blue corn and aged a minimum of 6 months in some sort of oak. It used to be aged in new, lightly charred American oak but I don’t see that on the bottle anywhere. Bottled at 46% ABV and features a curious, faintly green-tinged gold color. (The green is readily apparent if you hold it up to a light.)

Nose: Buttered corn. Loads of it. I’m tempted to double check that there aren't actually buttered corn kernels resting at the bottom of my glencairn. You can smell the corn cob, dusty husk, and all the rest. After wading through the corn maze, you are greeted with loads of vanilla and honey-drizzled bread. 

Palate: Holy buttered popcorn, Batman! Rich and oily mouthfeel with surprising amounts of spice and oaky astringency considering how little time this has spent in a barrel. Lightly salted, buttery nuts and spicy baked apple - I’m not sure how’d you’d prepare this kind of spicy baked apple, but it’s there. A floral and herbal quality so faint, it could just be mistaken for more corn notes. 

Finish: Starts sweet and a little leathery, but quickly returns to tannic oak. Somewhat reminiscent of a darkly roasted coffee but without the coffee’s overwhelming acidity. Very young and a bit harsh. Warming. 

Empty Glass: Buttered popcorn jelly beans. 

I know Distiller is just generally plotting the flavor, but I don’t see how the profile of Baby Blue is remotely close to Macallan 12 Year Old Double Cask. I won’t bother comparing and contrasting them here. In any case, while this is certainly an interesting dram to visit occasionally, I’d get bored of it quickly. It would be like ignoring all the other jelly beans and just seeking the buttered popcorn flavor. For the rest of your life. I can’t handle that much diacetyl (and it’s not because of my fears of popcorn lung disease).  

This is right around a 2.75 to 3.0 for me but I don’t like it as much as the other drams I’ve rated 3.0. I’m putting 2.75 but it’s more like a 2.9 from me. 

2.75 ~ 74 ~ Below Average
The classic balcones. Not at all cardboardy like the internet says. Sweet and full.
butter scotch and very sweet like cotton candy or vanilla frosting. Spicy and leathery on the palate.
Unique smell and flavor, better than most corn whiskies I've tried. A little sharp but you can actually taste the blue corn which is cool.
Buttery sweet candy corn. Light on the palette and a lingering taste of vanilla
Heavily buttered, burnt, carmel pop corn on the nose, sweet buttered corn, brown sugar and vanilla on the slightly creamy palate, the finish is short, sweet, slightly spicy and delicious.

I cant decide. I've had corn forward whiskey before, and I can't tell the difference here. The bartender tells me it is buttered popcorn. Alyssa tells me it's got an intense nose, smooth, but doesn't give a fuck.
This is special. Smells like caramel popcorn. Tastes young, but in a good way. Keeps a bit of alcohol heat that lingers. Very good for more adventurous drinkers.

At first, the nose was an aniseed note I don't like, but it opened up to a nice brown sugar. More brown sugar on the taste, with a spicy finish with a bit of corn dust. Nice. Not sure I'd get it again, but glad I tried it.

Nose has a lot of vanilla and caramel,

Taste is initially caramel, with little hints of sweetness. Not a ton of oak flavor because of how young it is. Very light texture. 

Really easy drinking. Great!
Little too peaty for me. Tastes like a scotch.

On the nose it reminds me of some corn new make that I have. It smells young. I get whiffs off cotton candy sweetness and buttered popcorn. The whisky is oily on the tongue, which I like, and decently rounded. Sweet and not hot at all. It finishes the same but with a lingering caramel corn.
Very smooth, light flavor. I like it!
Bananas and butterscotch on the nose and relatively soft on the palate. This pretty tasty considering it’s a 100% corn whisky
It tasted fresh and clean. Fruity, but kind of like the fruit wasn’t quite ripe yet. Not a huge fan. Like drinking a green banana.

Nose:  sweet, candy corn, agave, musty 
Palate: spicy, sweet, thick, corn, musty
Finish: medium length, sweet, moderately spicy

I’ll be honest, at first smell and taste this made me think of cheap tequila. I wasn’t sure how to describe it but that’s the thought that came to mind.  I really didn’t like it.  By the end of the glass it started to grow on me.  It is unique and interesting.  Definitely nothing like a standard bourbon, which is what I expected and probably why I was so put off at first.  I still think it has as much or more in common with tequila and bourbon.  Worth trying for the unique factor, but not my style.
To a refined palate,  this whiskey taste like ass with a corn cob in it.

This is unique. Not in a bad way, in a tasty way. It’s better than Mellow Corn, that is 100% for sure. It’s pretty sweet, which is what I find approachable. Not burny, not a lingering taste either. Just an easy pleasant supper.

Lots of vanilla and caramel on the nose.
Smooth finish
Sweet roasted corn. Oily, unique and delicious.

Nose: caramel banana, vanilla, oak

Tongue: thick in the mouth, baked apple , butter, salty, spices.

Finish: spice medium finish touch of sweetness 

For the price this is a great daily dram

First opened
No water

Nose - strong sweet corn, depending on distance either corn chip or creamed corn

Taste - sweet corn at the beginning, something fun on the finish.
Very earthy with a strong scent of corn.
Light and sweet on the nose. Maybe a sweet oat bread sent. Taste is a bit nutty with spice and a semi smooth finish.

Very young, indeed. Nose is corn (obviously...) pears and other sweet fruit, burnt caramel. subdued barrel notes linger.  Very distinct nose.
Gets more exciting on the palate.  It's sweet and lively, with a bit of an oily stickiness.  Soft slow rollout of corn-barrel-corn and other grain notes mixed with spices and a hint of saltiness.
It's interesting, for sure.  Probably not something I'd do again, but that's not because it isn't good...  I just prefer bourbon!
Incredibly sweet and fruity, a bit of spice on the back end. Mostly banana, overall pretty smooth.
A beguiling, almost tequila-esque aroma with very sweet notes. But the taste is simply too sweet, almost sickly so. Maybe this will grow on me but for now it’s more off-putting than appealing.
Roasted buttered corn followed by caramel and a light spice. Overall very interesting and enjoyable.
Better than Hudson Bay. Love the burnt sugary taste. This is a nice change of pace because it’s so unique.
has a lot of moonshine / straight corn whiskey flavor.  hot, but not as hot as moonshine.  more flavor than most straight corn.
Corn chips, sweet corn, creamed corn.  Good.  Really different than a lot of of other whiskeys.  Good, unique flavor.
A bit too subtle for my taste. The corn on the nose was pleasant.Too much fruitiness and perfume for my taste. I’m sure many people enjoy as its not offensive.
Nose is pancakes with lots of syrup, with a bit of corn and ethanol. Body is smooth with more pronounced corn and the finish is spicy with a bit of burn.

The nose is light with caramel and some grass. An interesting chalky scent comes out that makes it seem odd and reminds me of Corsair Quinoa's earthiness, though with a sweeter note rather than the bitter teabag scent mixed with dark fruits. It smells gross, like Lucky Charms (without the marshmallows) were steeped in it but with a bit of the malty, yeast still there. It certainly smells grainy. The palate has a bit of harshness - more than the nose suggests. The chalky grassiness immediately comes out and coats the tongue. The light caramel is there blending with the grass in a way that sort of works. The grain and grass intermingle here with the chalkiness (sort of like oatmeal dust) pervading. The grassiness here is a bigger problem than in Herradura Reposado because the citrus isn't present to add some bitterness and liven it up (also because tequila is supposed to taste more like vegetation). There's more sweetness here than in Herradura Reposado, but it's unbelievably grassy. The actual taste of oatmeal does come in too. Although the caramel doesn't have that fake, 6 month old sickly sweetness, it has a lightness that really makes it taste young. It tastes a lot like a reposado tequila; in fact, if you convinced me it was one I'd like it better. There is a nice hint of apricot on the finish, but it's more the thoroughly dried variety than the luxurious kind. On the long tail of the finish, there's a faint hint of coffee grounds. This isn't so much awful as it is weird, though it isn't really good either. Don Julio 1942 has some of the same flavor elements with the grainy variant on grassiness, but it is nowhere near as chalky and it has a much nicer caramel and more robust flavor. This tastes awful after trying Don Julio 1942, though I do get some of the subtleties coming out with the lightness. It's very interesting. The spice and smoke flavors are lightly present. There's plenty of vanilla, moving with a bit of a floral element. There's a little tartness but not too much. This is clearly predominantly corn (100%, as it turns out). I could believe that there was a small amount of rye in here, but wheat is definitely the closest other flavor that I get. Corsair is rich and luscious after drinking this, though with a bit of that Old Forester Signature flavor that lacks subtlety. Coming back to this drink, the mouthfeel is actually quite viscous and reminds me faintly of Don Julio 1942, but if Don Julio 1942 weren't very good. The complexity does eventually come out, saving this with a basket of grain flavors, but it never tastes great and the beginning is really rough. After every break - even just a minute long one - that painful first sip returns. Confusingly, the finish is substantially better than the nose or initial palate. Corsair Quinoa has a comparatively mild beginning and while it has fewer flavors in it, there's a rich, interesting quality to it that makes it more enjoyable. The finish on Corsair Quinoa evolves too, becoming more fruity with some more standard hedonistic notes of chocolate and tobacco.
Flaviar sample. Nose: sweet cream corn, caramel. Palate is pumpkin spice, honey, cedar, corn.
